intro: Matayba opaca var. fallax, commonly known as the Mexican ash or Mexican white ash, is a deciduous tree native to Central America and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Ulmaceae family, which includes ash and elm trees, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The tree produces small, winged fruits that are dispersed by wind, aiding in its propagation. Its bark is smooth and grayish in color, and it is often found in dry, open woodlands and along riverbanks. This variety is notable for its ornamental value and its ability to thrive in a range of soil conditions.
